𝚏-strings can be used to align content, e.g. for tabular contexts.
You can align center, left or right. https://t.co/ODCkGMSHVd
You can use 𝚏-strings for debugging. An equal sign will print out the name of a variable along with its value https://t.co/PjJmXc8rVg

If you liked that thread, please give the first tweet a Like or RT and follow me @bascodes for more content about programming!
 https://t.co/QaLmW81Ypv

Fortran

One of the first programming languages that added some abstraction on top of binary code, and later, Assembly, was Fortran. Appearing in 1957, it did not influence Python directly, but some parts of the numerical cores NumPy are based upon, are still written in Fortran. https://t.co/JbPeN3y9zM

Java

If programming languages were a popularity contest, we would see Python as mature, but still hip, and Java as a dinosaur of the software world.
But: Python is five years older than Java. 
Both drew the idea of OOP from languages like Simula and Smalltalk https://t.co/f7N2bQnK0j

APL

Probably the most obscure non-satiric programming language is APL. Back at the time, it even required a dedicated keyboard to enter all the symbols.
While it has not influenced Python directly, its ideas about matrix calculations can be seen to some extent in NumPy https://t.co/ocp50jIXmH

Occam

ABC itself drew the idea of indentation-based structuring from occam – presumably the first language to use indentation as part of its syntax https://t.co/Lej0EiF5qz

ABC

ABC is a language with Dutch roots, just like Python. Probably the most significant influences it had on Python are the structuring by indentation and the IN operator https://t.co/2oQkOBhHKE

Modula-3

Python borrowed some ideas from Modula-3 that have influenced programming languages other than Python, but never saw a notable adoption in the industry:
- self as an explicit parameter in class methods
- from x import y
- init as the name for constructors https://t.co/MYSMlRSYA7

C: The blocks

In some regards, the C programming language can be seen as the mother of most modern languages. It introduced “blocks” to structure programs, although they are limited by characters, not indentation https://t.co/vE7o1U1k8N

Did you enjoy this little thread about Python decorators? Leave a like or RT to the first tweet in the thread and follow me @bascodes!

https://t.co/4YItcvb7UW

To sum it up, a decorator is useful when you want something before and/or after each function call to be executed.
A popular example is the cache decorator: https://t.co/m2GMGH49Cn
In general, a decorator is able to extend the behaviour of a function without directly modifying it. We could, for example, log each call https://t.co/WPUCWBclmM

And, it has to return a callable to the decorated function, so that the decorated function remains accessible with its original name.
But why would we want something like that?
Since the two are equivalent, it's clear that the decorator itself has to be a function. https://t.co/Zb7x3KxXDu
First of all, the @-sign is equivalent to wrapping the function in a decorator. These two blocks are the same: https://t.co/LtdGeMiLEl

Our final index could then look like this: https://t.co/9V4Fv53Kij

1) Start with the columns that you'll use for equality checks, and order them by their cardinality (i.e. the number of distinct values in that column)

2) Put the columns for range checks (like price, or dates) at the end
Based on the query above, you'd consider an index covering the columns 𝚙𝚛𝚘𝚍𝚞𝚌𝚝_𝚌𝚊𝚝𝚎𝚐𝚘𝚛𝚢_𝚒𝚍, 𝚍𝚎𝚕𝚒𝚟𝚎𝚛𝚢, and 𝚙𝚛𝚒𝚌𝚎.

💡🗄️ Indexes can improve read performance on your SQL database significantly.

You can span an index across multiple columns.

However, the order of these columns matters.

9⃣ The Walrus Operator

With the walrus operator introduced in Python 3.8, you have an assignment expression.
That means that you could assign a value to a variable and access that value in the same line. https://t.co/7FTab8Uv2y

With a little experience in software development, it will get easier to pick up new languages. Do that! It will help you understand basic programming concepts better!

I get asked quite frequently which languages to learn. My answer is to pick either Python or JavaScript depending on the domain of your intended application. Then become proficient in one of them. And then learn the other one.
Python is more versatile in other areas of computing. Like data science, machine learning, and even desktop applications.
JavaScript shines in web dev. You can build frontends and backends with it very easily.
Python and JavaScript are both very versatile languages. There are many problems you can solve with either one of them.

Making healthy choices is important if you spend most of the day in front of a screen

If these tips helped you, give the first tweet of the thread a RT to help others, too!

#fitdevs #techlife

https://t.co/lQ5YIZxW4K

Here is what worked for me after two years of research and experimenting
https://t.co/lQ5YIZxW4K

7. Don't exaggerate 🏖️

There are probably more self-help books about dieting than about any other topic. I was trapped in the rabbit hole for a long time. Pick some advice and then follow it 80% Cravings are ok, don't overstretch your discipline. Enjoyment is part of the process

6. Stay hydrated 🥤

When I feel hungry, I'm most likely more thirsty than hungry. I drink a lot of water over the day and make sure I always have a full glass on my desk

5. Make a ritual 🥛

I can recommend making one meal or snack a ritual. For me, it's a cup of kefir before bedtime with a boiled egg or some avocado slices. I really enjoy it!

4. Eat good fat 🫒

I try to avoid deep-fried food as it contains lots of trans fats. Instead, I try to choose healthier fats like olive oil.

3. Avoid sugar 🍬

I try to avoid sugar as much as I can – I realized it really exaggerates energy levels from high to low. For consistent energy levels, I eat carbs from whole grains mostly

2. Add veggies to each meal 🥦

The more veggies I eat, the less space I have for crap food. So, my diet does not feel like a restriction but rather quality choices

1. Intermittent Fasting ⏰

I skip breakfasts. It's hard for the first couple of days but increases my energy so much and eliminates the afternoon low. I aim for an eating window between 6 and 8 hours each day.

I experienced a lot with dietary choices over the last two years 👨‍🍳

Here is what I found working to improve my energy during the day 👇 https://t.co/04m4gm7h58

8. Find a sparring partner

You're not alone. Find someone you can talk to about your feelings and stress levels. You'll notice that you're not alone. Talking with someone who shares your experiences can also help mutual motivation!

7. Set small goals

If you find it hard to start a task, just commit to 2 minds doing it. That's not a huge investment, but once you've started, the rest of the task will feel easier!

6. Practise gratitude

There are a lot of negative thoughts in all of us during a stressful day. Try to find one thing a day you're grateful for. If it's because someone made you feel better, tell them. Make a compliment to another person each day. Soon you'll walk with a smile.

5. Improve nutrition

I know what you think: Not another diet. 

Let me put it that way: What about replacing your only one candy bar snack a day with something of more nutritional value? A handful of nuts, a green smoothie, or an apple could work wonders.

4. Stay hydrated

Trivial but tremendously useful: Two-thirds of your body is water. Probably the easiest and cheapest way to improve your overall well-being is to take care of your water intake. Aim for at least 2 litres a day (half a gallon) – Drink more if you can.

3. Digital Detox

This again sounds hard and useless. But try to create your own experiences for one day rather than consuming Social Media or Netflix. Visit a museum, cook a delicious meal, or do something creative. This day will feel so much richer than binge-watching.

2. Take care of balance

Thinking about tech problems a whole day puts stress on your mind. Embed some physical activity in your day. Take a walk, hit the gym, or stretch for a short time each day, and you will feel more energized. 

I know it's hard to start, but give it a try

1. Improve your environment

You should love your job. That can be because of coworkers, your contribution to a larger thing, interesting challenges, or anything else. If you don't find anything positive, leave. Now!

Finally (line 5), the value of num is recalled and returned

Not too hard to follow Pythons bytecode, right?
Inside the loop (line 4), the interpreter loads the num variable, the i variable, multiplies these, stores the result to num, and then jumps to the beginning of the loop
The second block (line 3) loads the global range function, loads the value of the n variable and calls the range function. Then it creates a loop (GET_ITER and FOR_ITER)

Put it all together:
The first block (line 2) loads a constant (3) and stores it to a variable (n)
Finally, column (7) holds a human-readable interpretation.
Column (6) holds the operation's argument
Column (5) holds the name of the operation, often referred to as "opname"
Column (4) denotes the address in the bytecode – think of it as a line number for the interpreter
Column (3) contains a double arrow (>>) if it's a JUMP target – for example, one of a loop
Column (2) indicates the current instruction (unused in this example)
Column (1) indicates the line number in the source file.

Time Management

Deadlines are missed regularly in tech. Be sure to communicate clearly when you see a problem, but do your best to meet your deadlines. When multitasking, use serial time boxes rather than trying to do everything at once.

Positive Attitude and Emotional Intelligence

Everyone knows it: We sometimes have a bad day – and then there is this one co-worker supporting you, make you feel better and motivating you to finish that task. 

Be that co-worker!

Consulting Mindset and Good Communication Skills

Employers are looking for people who understand their business problems and then translate this into the right technology. You're not a coding monkey; you should become a consultant to your employer

Team Work

Today's jobs are no longer about the lone careerist who outperforms everyone. Complex tasks are always a team sport, so make sure you are a good team player!

Curiosity and Adaptability

Especially as a self-taught developer, you have already demonstrated that you can pick new stuff up very quickly. That's why #learninpublic is so important. 
Circumstances will change, so make sure you can adapt, too!
